items.question: According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design (DL/T 522-2019), when the external walls of two adjacent buildings are both non-combustible materials, and neither wall has any door or window openings or exposed combustible eaves, the fire separation distance may be reduced by 25%.

According to DL/T 522-2021 Technical Specifications for Substation Layout Design, to prevent the spread of fire and casualties in the event of an accident involving oil-immersed transformers or combustible medium capacitors, fire separation distances shall be established, and the number and opening methods of surrounding doors and windows shall be restricted.

According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design (inferred from the document title), when the relay room is located within the outdoor switchgear area, its clearance from the outdoor switchgear is entirely determined by the process discipline without reference to national or industry standards.

According to GB 50073-2013 'Methods for Measuring Environmental Vibration in Urban Areas' and substation design codes, the fire separation distance for substation buildings (including control buildings, GIS buildings, etc.) shall be calculated based on the closest distance between the external walls of adjacent buildings. Where external walls feature protruding combustible components, the distance shall be measured from the outer edge of such projections.

According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design, when constructing substations in mountainous or hilly regions, to reduce engineering costs and ensure slope stability, a stepped layout should be prioritised. Where feasible and subject to process requirements, large-scale earthworks (deep excavation and high filling) should be minimised.
